frontmatter.title: LeetCode 138. Copy List with Random Pointer

previous.body:
This problem was tricky as I had to track Node references rather than the index given in the input.

___

# Solution
```python
from collections import defaultdict
"""
# Definition for a Node.
class Node:
    def __init__(self, x: int, next: 'Node' = None, random: 'Node' = None):
        self.val = int(x)
        self.next = next
        self.random = random
"""

class Solution:
    def copyRandomList(self, head: 'Optional[Node]') -> 'Optional[Node]':
        start = Node(head.val) if head else None
        node = start
        randoms = defaultdict(list)
        nodes = {}
        while head:
            nodes[head] = node
            node.next = Node(head.next.val) if head.next else None
            node.val = head.val
            if head.random:
                randoms[head.random].append(head)
            head = head.next
            node = node.next
        
        for val in randoms.keys():
            for neighbor in randoms[val]:
                nodes[neighbor].random = nodes[val]

        return start
```
O(n) = n since worst case is 2n due to the while loop, then at most visiting each node again when assigning the randoms' value.

next.body:
I had difficulties with this problem with terminating completed lists. I was surprised that ChatGPT didn't give this simple solution, 
it suggested a large rework. I'll have to be mindful before implementing all of ChatGPT's suggestions.

___

# Solution
```python
# Definition for singly-linked list.
# class ListNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.next = next
class Solution:
    def reverseKGroup(self, head: Optional[ListNode], k: int) -> Optional[ListNode]:
        batch = []
        start = None
        curr = None
        while head:
            batch.append(head)
            head = head.next
            if len(batch) == k:
                if curr:
                    curr.next = batch.pop()
                    curr = curr.next
                else:
                    curr = batch.pop()
                    if not start:
                        start = curr
                     
                while batch:
                    curr.next = batch.pop()
                    curr = curr.next
                
        if batch and curr:
            curr.next = batch[0]
        elif batch:
            start = batch[0]
        elif not batch and curr:
            curr.next = None
        
        return start
```
Time complexity is O(n) = n and space complexity is O(k).

post.body:
I was able to reduce this time complexity from  O(n) = 2n to O(n) = n by using a list for the elements to be reversed, and then only modifying those rather than stepping through all nodes while reversing.

___

# Solution
```python
# Definition for singly-linked list.
# class ListNode:
#     def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):
#         self.val = val
#         self.next = next
class Solution:
    def reverseBetween(self, head: Optional[ListNode], left: int, right: int) -> Optional[ListNode]:
        first = head
        start = None
        end = None
        last = None
        toReverse = []
        i = 0
        while i < right:
            if i == max(left - 2, 0):
                start = head
            if i == right - 1:
                end = head
            if i >= left - 1 and i < right - 1:
                toReverse.append(head)
            head = head.next
            i += 1
        
        last = end.next
        if left > 1:
            start.next = end
            start = start.next
        else:
            start = end
            first = start
        head = start
        while toReverse:
            head.next = toReverse.pop()
            head = head.next
        if head.next:
            head.next = last

        return first
```
